For those that doubted:

The TVLA website explains that “every TV contains a component called the ‘local oscillator’, which emits a signal when the television is switched on. It’s this signal that the equipment on our vans picks up. But, what if you live in a block of flats or a house without road access? Well if this is the case our enquiry officer can simply use one of our hand-held scanners. Measuring both direction and strength of signal, they make it easy for us to locate television sets in hard to reach places.”

I thought it was common knowledge, my apologies for not better explaining.
[/quote]
I wonder if my TV capture card has one of those “local oscillator”'s… Might have to not pay the licence!

Oh well, not like I’ve seen one of their “vans” ever before.[/quote]
You’re not supposed to see them…

item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:33, topic:364703”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=460911.msg3376554#msg3376554 date=1287665463]

Even if you don’t think it’s worth it, you can watch programmes an hour later on iplayer.

You can’t actually, not legally anyway. To watch TV shows on iPlayer/Youtube etc. you need a TV License.

How would they enforce that?
[/quote]
“You need to be covered by a valid TV Licence if you watch or record TV as it’s being broadcast. This includes the use of devices such as a computer, laptop, mobile phone or DVD/video recorder.”

If you are capable of receiving television you must pay.
So basically just having a computer connected to the internet means you must have a tv licence even if you don’t own a television or use your computer to stream broadcasts.[/quote]
It doesn’t state that if you are capable of receiving live television you must pay - only if you actually watch it. It’s the same as just owning a TV for gaming. If they can’t prove you actually watch terrestrial TV, they can’t prosecute you for just owning one.

item.title: I'm proud of the BBC
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:41, topic:364703”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=460911.msg3376798#msg3376798 date=1287691197]

I laugh at all the ignorant people over here who complain at having to pay for a TV license. It’s a great idea, but it could only be done by one broadcaster in each country (otherwise you’d be paying too many “license” fees).

It’s great because it’s ad free. I don’t watch TV - I download everything - unless I’m watching BBC and I’ll happily continue to pay a license fee for that reason.

I get wound up by people who say it should be scrapped (there’s lots of facebook groups) because they’re total morons, they’re asking for the same service without the fee. How stupid do you have to be to think that’s financially viable for any company. If the license was scrapped and tomorrow the BBC had adverts instead I’d bet every single member of those groups would complain to have it changed back.

I’m against the license, it should be payed by the tax instead, like most public services. The way it is today, it is like an extra tax given to everybody, without caring about income.
[/quote]

It’s not included in tax because certain people are exempt from tax, for instance students don’t need to pay council tax, if it were taxed it would be a lot more awkward to collect, and you’d probably end up paying more as they’d need more complex ways of catching people who aren’t paying (currently involves just scanning a house from the outside). However your point on income is definitely valid, but you could argue the same for just about anything; Cheaper food for lower income families! (for instance)

Although it’s really not that much money.[/quote]
You’re right in what you say there, but thats not what I meant. The expenses for BBC and other public broadcasters should be payed like other things, for the tax money. Students should not need to pay, in Norway it is on €300, and students need that money they have.

Yes, lower income families can get cheaper food, they can choose different types of food and save money that way. When it comes to TV it either TV or no TV, you can’t choose away BBC, but you can choose away expensive food.
